column15: Scrap spread is LME copper price minus No.2 copper scrap (birch) price

Monthly data frequency, in linear form such that each kt increase in world copper inventory causes a 0.633 USD/t decrease in copper price, adjusted using correlation between LME inventory and global supply-demand imbalance
In linear form such that each kt increase in world concentrate inventory causes a 0.164 USD/t payable copper increase in TCRC
Monthly data frequency, in linear form such that each 1 USD/t increase in copper cathode price causes a 0.184 USD/t increase in No.2 copper scrap (birch) spread
Product of scrap spread elasticity to primary price and price elasticity to supply-demand imbalance
Use the difference between current price and its five-year average
Hard to tell how many regressors were actually used

column1: Mean percent change per year in cumulative ore treated
column15: For all mines already open in 1991 that had a start year given, assumed those mines operated with 1991 ore treated from start year to 1991. Steel was given the average of the other commodities.

Used base metals results for tin and aluminum. Hausman test deemed random effects unsuitable for Zinc and base metals, used fixed effects model in those cases. Platinum value is 3.09. Degrees of freedom vary across commodity: Cu=3749, Au=3828, Pb=174, Ni=940, Sn=357, Pt=357, Ag=711, Zn=1948, Base metals=6916. Regression also included oil price to account for energy costs.

column1: Mine cost elasticity to ore grade
column15: Used base metals results for tin and aluminum. Hausman test deemed random effects unsuitable for Zinc and base metals, used fixed effects model in those cases. Platinum value is -0.3486. Degrees of freedom vary across commodity: Cu=3749, Au=3828, Pb=174, Ni=940, Sn=357, Pt=357, Ag=711, Zn=1948, Base metals=6916. Regression also included oil price to account for energy costs.

column1: Ore grade elasticity to COT distribution mean
column15: Simple average percent decline in mean ore grade per year (weighted using recovered metal at each mine for which data were available)

column1: Ore grade elasticity to COT distribution mean
column3: Random effects and fixed effects panel models, depending on Hausman test
column15: Represents the mean ore grade decline at each mine per year, rather than the mean ore grade decline of the entire commodity, degrees of freedom were: Cu=4041, Au=4042, Pb=190, Ni=981, Pt=377, Ag=721, Zn=2115. Random effects models were used for Au, Ni; all others used fixed effects based on Hausman test. Value for platinum was 2.0

column1: Ore grade elasticity to COT distribution mean
column3: Random effects and fixed effects panel models, depending on Hausman test
column15: Represents the percent ore grade decline per percent increase in cumulative ore treated, degrees of freedom were: Cu=4041, Au=4042, Pb=190, Ni=981, Pt=377, Ag=721, Zn=2115. Only copper used a random effects model based on Hausman test. Value for Pt was -0.025 (meaning increasing grade)
